results.title: The Homecoming
results.creator_credit: Peter Hall, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Lauded and much admired adaptation of the caustic Harold Pinter play about three estranged brothers and their father. When one son - an accomplished university professor - visits from America with his wife, the family are reunited in their London home only to find that tension and malevolence simmers dangerously below their every interaction. As a study of male violence, family dysfunction, rage and suppressed emotion, Pinter’s screenplay shines even if the characters’ motivations are opaque, and their capacity for hatred, disturbing. Cast includes: Vivien Merchant, Terence Rigby, Paul Rogers, Cyril Cusack, Michael Jayston, and Ian Holm who is brilliant as the menacing pimp, Lenny.

results.title: Rhinoceros
results.creator_credit: Tom O'Horgan, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
A satirical comedy about bored and alcoholic office worker Stanley (Gene Wilder) and his friend John (Zero Mostel) who bare witness to a strange ‘illness’ in which fellow human beings slowly turn into Rhinos. A film rendition of Eugene Ionesco’s play, part of Theater of the Absurd, “Rhinoceros” looks to explore the themes of conformity in society and keeping-up-appearances. Will Stanley be able to resist becoming one of the herd and maintain his individuality? This low budget film has some compelling performances, particularly that of Mostel when he makes his transition to the animal kingdom and some wacky black comedy situations, such as a stampede of Rhinos (that are left to the imagination to see) that take out the stairs of the office leaving Stanley and his workmates stranded. Stanley has his own particularly simple attitude: “I’m indifferent to life, so I take a few drinks and then it doesn’t bother me anymore.” Cast includes Karen Black, Joe Silver, Robert Weil.

results.title: Eugene O'Neill's: The Iceman cometh
results.creator_credit: John Frankenheimer, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
In this searing film adaptation of Eugene O’Neill’s play, Robert Ryan stars as Larry, a barfly and self proclaimed philosopher eagerly awaiting death all but for his iron constitution. He and his gang of drunk cronies anticipate the periodical visit of Hickey (Lee Marvin) who usually turns up in a generous mood and with generous purse for the bar owner Harry (Frederic March) and the whole gang. This time, however, he is late in arriving and everyone is on edge and the anticipation of the bender they are about to go on is rousing them out of their alcoholic stupor. Hickey’s visit doesn’t bring them the fun they were hoping for; he instead challenges them all to forget their hopes and dreams and deal with reality. He is especially hard on Larry but his words affect more deeply the young Don Parritt (Jeff Bridges) whose relationship with his mother is a reality too hard for him to bear.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Frankenheimer, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films

results.title: The Combat film
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, Danielle Gardner, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “American cinema”.
Beginning with World War II combat films which were produced under U.S. Federal Government directives, this program examines the role of the combat film in filling a social and political need. Critics and directors describe the evolution of these films, the rise of the Vietnam film and the influence of newsreel documentaries and television news on the genre.

results.title: Romantic comedy
results.creator_credit: Molly Ornati, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “American cinema”.
Breezy and silly to witty and intelligent, romantic comedies have been around since the 1930’s but the surface humour barely masked issues of gender and sexuality. This program reviews screwball comedies including “It happened one night” and “His girl Friday” and analyses more recent interpretations of the genre by directors like Nora Ephron and James Brooks.

results.title: American cinema
results.creator_credit: Greg Martinelli, Molly Ornati, Rita Mate, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description: A 13 part series examining the cinema industry. Producers, directors, actors, cinematographers and Hollywood stars reveal insights into the business of making motion pictures. John Lithgow introduces each episode which encompasses a theme and examines it in detail with clips from some of the world’s renown films.

results.title: Classical Hollywood style today
results.creator_credit: Greg Martinelli, Lorna Thomas, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “American cinema”.
This program offers interviews with contemporary directors, European film-makers, scholars, critics and studio-era veterans who probe Hollywood’s influence on both American and world culture.

results.creator_credit: Richard Smigielski, Brian Street, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “American cinema”.
Provides a formal and cultural analysis of a classical film sequence serving as a critical how-to guide for those new to film critique.

results.title: The Edge of Hollywood
results.creator_credit: Saskia Baron, Shana Swanson, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “American cinema”.
While many of the old rules are still in force, independent filmmakers often add their dissineting voices to the forum. This program looks at some alternative visions from new talents including Spike Lee, Joel and Ethan Coen, Jim Jarmusch and Quentin Tarantino. With limited budgets, they are challenging the stylistic status quo of the Hollywood film.
